title: Rook's Rest
description: A square, compact stone prison at the island’s core, guarded within and without. Only one gate in—and none out, for most.

title: Eastchain Docks
description: Eastchain Docks is a sprawling network of quays, piers, and slipways lining the east bank of the Koln River—where merchant vessels, fishing boats, and makeshift shanties intermingle beneath the watchful cranes and market lanterns.

title: Breakbay Docks
description: The Breakbay Docks themselves are a vast, sheltered quayside carved into the stone shore of the bay, featuring heavy-duty piers and towering gantry cranes. Deep-water berths accommodate the city’s largest ocean-going vessels, while gangways and mooring lines spider across the water. Built of reinforced concrete and steel, the docks are bathed in the constant hiss of winches and the low throb of diesel engines, a sprawling gateway between Kolnmark and the wider world.

title: Caskside Docks
description: A tangle of piers and warehouses where loaded barges wait at all hours.

title: Drummond's Mill
description: A large and sprawling lumbermill found at the Southern edge of the Island. Drummond's has ruthlessly consumed all of the nearby independent mills in a bid to control the industry.

title: Sootsmiths
description: The various businesses located on the South side of the island that concern themselves with the generation and sale of charcoal to city residents.

title: The Blackspans
description: Twin stone bridges, ancient and scarred, linking the island to both city banks. Caravans and patrols cross at all hours.

title: The Blackspans
description: Twin stone bridges, ancient and scarred, linking the island to both city banks. Caravans and patrols cross at all hours.

title: Westgate
description: A massive stone arch set into Kolnmark’s western wall, flanked by stout guard towers. Here, travelers and merchants present papers and tolls before stepping onto the Timber Road, as sentries scan the horizon for riverfolk and caravans alike.

title: Market Gate
description: Main entrance to the lower city. Commonly congested with temporary stalls from rural vendors.

title: Twin Gates
description: Main entrance to the upper city. Gilded twin gates.

title: The Spine
description: Ramped causeway that connects the Lower and Upper cities.

title: Southern Logflume
description: Also called the Widowmaker, it is the shifting mass of logs queued for processing that oftentimes chokes the River Koln. Site of some of the most daring and/or stupid of Coinmarches residents.

title: Logjumpers
description: A local tavern bearing the nickname of one of the major careers of the island. Usually full of off-shift workers from the mill or other businesses.

title: Drivers Union Hall
description: Recently renovated after a destructive fire, it contains the various offices of union administrators and a meeting hall for local log drivers.

title: Breaker Beacon
description: A short, soot-stained lighthouse at the North end of the island. Has long served as a navigation tool for mariners and barge captains.

title: Barrelmaster's Plaza
description: Open-air market where coopers auction off the finest casks at dawn.

title: Master Cooper's Hall
description: The guild’s stone-hewn lodge, ringed with staves drying on outdoor racks.

title: Iron Stave Distillery
description: Kolnmark's premier distiller. Brass pipes hiss and copper stills glow beneath a cloud of sweet steam.

title: The Rare Sip
description: A newly-opened taphouse that debuts experimental local spirits, barrel-aged ales, and boutique wines straight from the cooper’s trade.  Its smoky-oak interior and nightly tastings draw connoisseurs citywide.

title: Bridgehead Tavern
description: Nestled at the foot of the western Blackspan bridge, this lively inn is famed for its riverside view and nightly “Bridge Barrel” tastings—experimental casks brought straight from Caskside’s cooperies.

title: The Stave & Straw
description: A no-frills flophouse tucked nestled next to the outwer wall. For a handful of coppers, local coopers, log-drivers and mash-house hands secure a plank bed and a straw sack—but the lingering tang of fermenting grain promises little in the way of peaceful slumber.

title: Westgate Terrace
description: The long brick thoroughfare leading from the city’s western gate into Newbrick, lined with elm trees and early morning bakeries.

title: Teamsters Unionhall
description: A stout, circular brick lodge by the riverbank where log-drivers, cart-masters and haulers gather for wage negotiations, equipment exchanges and nightly camaraderie. Its broad colonnade echoes with the clank of harnesses and the thud of empty barrels.

title: Settlers’ Market
description: Held daily in Market Plaza, farmers and artisans haggle over fresh fruit, crafted wares and other goods shipped in via the Timber Road or the River Koln.

title: Riverstone Shrine
description: A gleaming marble temple by the riverside, where bargemen and millers leave votive stones for good fortune.

title: Riverstone Park
description: A landscaped greenbelt stretching between the shrine and the river wall, dotted with benches hewn from Koln’s own white marble.  Flowerbeds of blue irises sway in the breeze, and a trickling fountain of river-worn stone offers a quiet retreat for families and passers-by.

title: Brickwall Flats
description: A compact tenement block near the Westgate, offering modest rooms to craft apprentices and seasonal laborers.

title: Artisans’ Arcade
description: A covered colonnade of forty small workshops, famous for its annual “Night of Sparks” forging festival.

title: Craftside Market
description: A stretch of pop-up stalls and carts that line the main road each morning, vanishing by dusk.

title: Blackspan Overlook
description: A little plaza set atop a flight of stone steps, offering a framed view of both bridges and the river below.

title: Journeymen’s Guild Hall
description: A stout, half-timbered building at the district’s western end, its notice board covered with job postings and apprenticeships.

title: The Painted Mask Playhouse
description: A modest timber-framed theatre tucked between storefronts, where groundlings squeeze into bench seating for raucous comedies and traveling troupes debut new folk dramas beneath flickering lanterns.

title: The Greenwold
description: A sprawling urban park at the heart of Lower Kolnmark, where the city’s main east–west and north–south avenues meet. Winding gravel paths thread through copses of chestnut and elm, manicured flowerbeds and open lawns, all centered on a grand marble fountain.

title: Bright Tent Square
description: The twisted center of the district where stalls crowd every inch of open space, lit by swinging lanterns and the roar of haggling voices.

title: Marionette Court
description: A makeshift wooden stage at the north end of the square, where the weekly puppet show dazzles audiences with masterful craftsmanship.

title: Shady Lane
description: A back-alley thoroughfare of shuttered warehouses and hidden courtyards, favored by unlicensed merchants and smuggler contacts.

title: Brickfall Tenements
description: A row of crumbling brick buildings at the district’s southern edge, their sagging balconies home to dozens of families.

title: The Ragged Tankard & Scarlet Parlour
description: A low-ceilinged tavern of warped floorboards and foul ale served in chipped mugs; a tattered velvet drape behind the bar leads to the Scarlet Parlour, a cramped, candlelit brothel where the district’s poorest trade coin for comfort.

title: The Pockmarks
description: Two overcrowded isles offshore, ringed by mudflats, where improvised huts and beached longboats cluster, inhabited by fishermen, squatters and those seeking refuge from the city’s reach.

title: Gilded Crane Market
description: A string of open-air stalls under lantern canopies, purveying foreign wares and attracting buyers from across the city.

title: Shipwright Row
description: A rutted lane of tide-slicked workshops and lumber yards, alive with the ring of hammers on iron and the saw of blade on oak as master shipwrights and apprentices hew and plank vessels of every size.

title: Cargo Staging Grounds
description: A broad, open yard crisscrossed by rails and block-and-tackle, piled high with crates of coal, barrels of oil, exotic imports and raw timber—each bay watched by clerks, cranes and the idle eyes of hired muscle.

title: The Anchor’s Rest
description: A low-ceilinged sailors’ lounge tucked between two busy docks, its lantern-lit common room thick with tar smoke and salt air, where mariners swap sea-shanties, tall tales and the day’s best bets over brimming mugs of grog.

title: Temple of the Silver Tides
description: A stilted wooden pavilion rising above the mudflats, its rough-hewn beams and bleached driftwood walls hung with carved figureheads and weathered fishing floats. Inside, a slatted floor lets river breezes carry the scent of salt and incense, where seafarers slip offerings of shell, oar-shaft and coin into creaking prayer chests for tide-fair winds and safe returns.

title: Marshaling Grounds
description: Wide open stone expanse ringed by loading cranes, rails and inspection booths—where every crate and barrel is weighed, stamped and warranteed.

title: Customs Hall
description: A fortified stone pavilion of high arched windows, where imported treasures and staples alike pass under the scrutiny of the city’s revenue collectors.

title: Dockmaster’s Office
description: The operational hub of harbor traffic, its weathered plaques and signal yard alive with semaphore flags, whistles and ringing bells.

title: Pinnacle Lighthouse
description: Perched on the very tip of The Point, its ever-burning beacon and spiraling stair are both a landmark for sailors and a symbol of Kolnmark’s mastery over the river.

title: The Golden Keel
description: A polished stone and mahogany tavern catering to city functionaries, ship captains, and trade barons, where crystal goblets clink and discreet ledgers exchange hands over single-malt spirits and imported vintages.

title: Banded Warehouse
description: A fortress-like stone depot ringed by iron bars and watchtowers, where seized cargos and high-value imports are locked behind heavy doors and guarded around the clock by customs officers.

title: Gilded Spectacle Playhouse
description: A landmark stage where the city’s best actors and actresses perform under crystal chandeliers.

title: Luna’s Lantern
description: A house of mirth, charted on every captain’s map.

title: Harmonium Hall
description: The district’s architectural jewel, hosting orchestras and civic ceremonies on its river-facing terrace.

title: Pilots’ Guildhall
description: A sturdy, half-timbered brick building on the north quay where licensed river pilots train, lodge and coordinate the comings and goings of vessels. Inside, walls hung with navigational charts and racks of sextants overlook a vaulted meeting hall where pilots plan dawn departures, sound signal horns and settle disputes over tricky currents.

title: Quarantine Depot
description: A squat stone building on the southern spit, where arriving crews are briefly detained and their cargoes fumigated to guard against pests and plague. Whitewashed walls and iron-barred windows give it a forbidding air.

title: The Iron Sheds
description: Endless rows of corrugated-steel warehouses rising from the water’s edge, each door stamped with a number. Within lie coils of anchor chain, crates of machinery, and pallets of exotic goods awaiting transit.

title: Spit Tarworks
description: A cluster of low, smoky sheds on the eastern shore where pitch and tar are boiled in huge cauldrons to seal and preserve wooden hulls. Acrid vapors drift over the quay, and black-stained barrels wait in neat rows.

title: Grand Maritime Exchange
description: A row of dignified granite-fronted halls lining the quay, their arched porticos draped in signal flags and rigging. Inside, tall windows flood broker’s chambers where timber-smoke drifts through ledgers and charts, and captains, merchants, and freight-brokers haggle over cargo space with the clink of silver and the creak of ship timbers ever in the background.

title: Saltwood Figurehead Atelier
description: A petite workshop where master carvers coax elegant figureheads and ornamental trim from gnarled driftwood. Inside, the scent of tallow, fresh sawdust, and brine mingle as captains and shipowners commission bespoke prows and rail-carvings to lend their vessels character on every voyage.

title: Hall of Records
description: A gated, walled complex with columned porticos opening onto a central courtyard. Here contested deeds, civic petitions, and lower-city permits are filed, indexed, and archived in endless vellum volumes.

title: Quill & Ink Emporium
description: A narrow, gorgeously appointed shop at the Greenwold corner, where fine goose-quills and imported inks are weighed and sold by the dram to every weary clerk.

title: Parchment Rest
description: A shaded tea pavilion in the Hall’s courtyard, where petitioners sip spiced herbal blends while they wait for their names to be called.

title: Ledger Lane
description: A short cobbled alley lined with small stamp dealers, seal-carvers, and petition-drafters—essential support trades for anyone navigating the Ward’s bureaucracy.

title: Riverside Promenade
description: A shaded stone walkway along the Koln’s eastern bank, where river breeze cools grand homes and ferry landings alike.

title: Hearthrow Market
description: Tucked against the old city wall, this compact square hosts stalls of fresh produce, yard goods, and everyday wares—open dawn to dusk.

title: Tenement Court
description: A tight courtyard of brick-faced lodging for Hearthrow’s working families. Laundry sways overhead and children play around its central well.

title: Boutique Row
description: A narrow lane of shuttered shopfronts selling fine leatherwork, hand-blown glass, and bespoke millinery—serving the district’s middle classes.

title: Riverview Hall
description: A pillared red-brick manor crowned with slate turrets and overlooking the ferry landing. Its long colonnaded veranda serves afternoon teas, while crystal lanterns glow across the river at dusk.

title: Willowbank Manor
description: A graceful stone-and-ivy estate set on terraced lawns that slope down to the Koln’s eastern bank. Built by the venerable Elwood family, its arched windows and wrought-iron balustrades catch every sunset over the river.

title: Greenwold Pavilion
description: A light-filled, glass-fronted lounge nestled where Hearthrow meets the Greenwold. Ornate trellises of climbing roses frame arched doors onto the park, and weekends find musicians and dancers entertaining beneath its vaulted roof.

title: Market Gate Arch
description: The ornate stone archway through which all northern trade must pass. Its carved reliefs depict the city’s founding and still bear scorch marks from past sieges.

title: Tenement Square
description: A quiet courtyard ringed by four-story rowhouses, where neighbors gather to share meals and gossip in the evenings.

title: The Rusty Bolt
description: A cozy, low-rent tavern tucked down a back alley, famous for its strong ale and nightly group game of dice.

title: Rivercity Clayworks
description: A squat brick building with tall chimneys on a bend of the Koln. Local potters utilized dredged river-clay here to craft tiles, bricks and sturdy vessels used throughout the district.

title: Chapel of the Heartstone
description: A modest white-stone shrine set amid stables and smithies. Artisans pause here each morning to leave a chip of iron or clay in thanks for steady hands.

title: Trinity Hall
description: A triangular service center at the Spire’s lower entrance, housing the Spire’s administrative offices, a clerical registry, and a small public chapel; its three wings converge on a central atrium where aid and counsel are offered to pilgrims and city servants.

title: Silver Court
description: Four stately town-homes arranged around a cobblestone courtyard, where clipped hedges hide iron-bound presses used by local guild-artisans.

title: The Roundhouse
description: A circular pavilion on the district’s West flank, its marble colonnade opening onto the Greenwold for morning devotions.

title: Portico Manor
description: A large square mansion topped by a grand portico overlooking the northern gardens; once a private retreat for the Archbishop, now used for formal receptions.

title: Spirewright’s Forge
description: A modest brick workshop near the Spire’s outer gate where master blacksmiths forge the iron fittings and brass inlays used in the tower’s doors and bells.

title: Acolyte’s Apothecary
description: A half-timbered shop set into a row of clerical cottages, offering scented oils, blessed incense, and simple remedies to priests and visitors.

title: Market Gate Plaza
description: The heart of Wallwrights, this paved square rings with stalls and covered booths selling cut stone, stained-glass shards, polished metal fittings, and imported decorative veneers. A stone fountain at its center depicts the wall’s mythical founding.

title: Spire Stoneworks
description: A long row of workshops beneath the shadow of the Spire, where master masons hew and finish the blocks destined to repair or expand the Spire. Their dust motes drift into the street like snow.

title: Gleamsmith Forge
description: A turreted building of blackened brick where glass-blowers and metal-casters share a single great chimney. Here the colored window panels and gilded grilles for the Spire take form.

title: Ivorycarver’s Row
description: A narrow lane of cramped shops specializing in carved bone, ivory, and mother-of-pearl fittings—mantle inlays, reliquary panels, and high-status door pulls. Few craftsmen earn the prestige (or price) of a true “celeste sculptor.”

title: The Idle Implement
description: A two-story timber-and-stone guild hall at the district’s southern end, with a roaring hearth, long communal tables, and billiards. Here masons, smiths, and glass‐workers unwind over hearty stews and ale, swap techniques, and recruit journeymen for new commissions.

title: The Silver Lantern Inn
description: A five-story granite lodge whose private balconies offer direct views of the Spire’s lantern chamber. Known for its violet-scented baths and “Pathfinder’s Suite.”

title: Spireview Pavilion
description: An open-air tea garden perched atop a gradual rise; fountains whisper beneath trellises of jasmine and tea-leaf topiary.”

title: Sanctum Steps
description: A graceful flight of carved marble stairs leading to a halved chapel façade. Pilgrims light floating lanterns each dawn in the reflecting pool below.

title: Celestial Quill Scriptorium
description: Tucked into the northern edge of Pilgrim’s Way where it meets the Clerk’s Ward, this elegant workshop specializes in hand-inscribed prayer scrolls, gilded hymnals, and bespoke devotional pens. Its stained-glass windows glow softly at dusk, drawing clerks and clergy seeking finely crafted liturgical implements.

title: Northern Star Auditorium
description: A sector-shaped hall on the district’s northern fringe, its sweeping curved façade facing the Clerk’s Ward. Inside, tiered benches fan out from a raised dais beneath a vaulted, lantern-lit ceiling. Renowned for its crystalline acoustics, it hosts orations, sacred choirs, and intimate recitals in the Spire’s shadow.

title: Cliffside Market
description: A narrow promenade of stalls and lean-tos at the cliff’s base, trading everything from salted halibut to hand-woven baskets beneath the great stone overhang.

title: Stonehaven Warehouse
description: A squat, windowless storehouse built against the cliffs’ northern wall. Rumored to hold imported silks and rare spices, its single barred door is watched day and night by hooded sentries.

title: Spireview Terrace
description: A row of modest yet well-kept homes perched in full southern sun, offering their residents rare views of the Spire’s glowing lanterns at dusk.

title: Westbank Tenements
description: A block of sturdy brick walk-ups on the west side, arranged around a shared cobbled courtyard. Weathered murals of fishing boats decorate the walls, and every porch rings with the clatter of children’s games.

title: Salt Vaults
description: A labyrinth of cliff-hewn caverns kept at near-freezing temperature, where perishable goods and salted provisions are stored in brine pools.

title: Ironhook Foundry
description: A ring of open-hearth forges spewing sparks into the twilight, renowned for casting the finest swords and halberds in Kolnmark.

title: The Mercenary’s Anvil
description: A busy smithy and gear-shop whose walls are hung with custom blades, greaves and gauntlets made to order.

title: Hook & Hammer Tavern
description: A stout stone inn where sellswords convene over spiced ale; private booths upstairs serve as impromptu contract halls.

title: The Common Arsenal
description: A vaulted stone warehouse storing pikes, crossbows, training dummies, and raw kit for all companies.

title: Barracks Mess Hall
description: A timberhewn building equipped with long communal tables under pennants of every company, where stew and ale flow to the clamor of soldier’s tales.

title: Fires of Fortitude Sauna
description: A heated granite chamber rigged with steam jets and plunge pools, where steel-hardened troops cleanse bruises and bond in silence.

title: Steelhawks Company Barracks
description: The Company barracks for the Steelhawks.

title: Black Banner Barracks
description: The Company barracks for the Black Banner Company.

title: Crimson Vultures Barracks
description: The Company barracks for the Crimson Vulture.

title: The Oath House
description: A vast, multi-winged building with a central courtyard. Company banners line its halls, where mercenary captains sign contracts and share muster fees.

title: The Twist
description: A tight cluster of wooden stalls at the district’s north edge. Vendors sell crusty bread, bartered armor scraps, and all-night gaming tables.

title: The Broken Barrel Tavern
description: A low-ceilinged dive with chipped tables and sour ale. Knife-throwing boards line the back wall, and coin-hungry barkeeps settle disputes with ale-soaked fists.

title: The Velvet Fang
description: A muli-story house of ill repute tucked into a narrow side-street. Crimson lanterns glow at its entrance; inside, silk drapes, perfumed air, and hushed laughter mask the desperate hopes—and darker deals—of its patrons.

title: Cliff Cove Dock
description: An impressive deep-water berth in the lower city’s northern reaches, lined with creaking cranes and warehouses.

title: The Haulout
description: A narrow strip of sand where small craft are beached for hull repairs and cleaning.

title: Sea Wall
description: A continuous stone barrier, heavily buttressed and built to protect the cove from heavy seas.

title: Causeway Lifts
description: Two colossal winch-driven platforms that hoist cargo up the cliff face to the upper city.

title: Engineers’ Watchtower
description: A squat stone tower overlooking the lifts, where shore engineers monitor every turn of the winch.

title: The Rusted Anchor
description: A weather-beaten tavern perched on pilings at the water’s edge. Inside, dockhands and lift-crews drink brine-spiced ales and swap sea-tales beneath lanterns made from old buoy glass.

title: Harborstone Forge
description: A smoke-blackened smithy tucked into the cliff’s base, where ironworkers hammer out anchors, pulley components, and lift-gear for the causeway stations. The clang of hammer on anvil echoes across the cove.

title: The Embering Flare
description: A low-rent tavern built into a collapsed arch, its smoky hearth and potent spirits attract both fishermen and cutpurses after dark.

title: Shale Slip Docks
description: Three makeshift jetties of fallen masonry where small fishing skiffs beach at low tide and fish change hands at dawn.

title: Columnar Market
description: A cramped open market arrayed around a single massive Causeway pillar, trading in cast-off tools, worn clothing, and “miracle” tonics.

title: The Hollowed Vault
description: A clandestine speakeasy carved into the Causeway’s footing; vaulted stone ceilings echo with laughter, music, and whispered transactions.

title: Giant's Causeway
description: A raised ruined causeway used as a military parade and training ground.

title: The Octal Rotunda
description: A great circular hall divided by eight radial corridors, each devoted to one of the city’s leading mercenary companies. Command councils and contract signings take place beneath its vaulted dome.

title: The Clang
description: A narrow street of interlinked workshops where master smiths forge swords, siege hammers, and intricately tooled pikes to outfit entire companies.

title: Ledger Hall
description: A fortified complex of vaulted chambers and brass-bound ledgers, Ledger Hall serves as the administrative heart for Swordcrest’s companies. Inside, clerks in tabard-lined cubicles pore over muster rolls, negotiate contract amendments, and process payroll requisitions. A vast rotating ledger wheel in the central chamber displays every active hire, payment schedule, and obligation—ensuring captains, recruiters, and quartermasters keep their companies in service and fully supplied.

title: Viewing Hall
description: A raised pavilion of glass and steel overlooking the Causeway. Foreign diplomats and highborn patrons watch live demonstrations of tactics before negotiating contracts over lavious drinks and meals.

title: The Spire
description: A looming, austere tower visible across the city — home to the city’s dominant faith.

title: Sundermere Court
description: At the northern edge, this white-stuccoed villa belongs to Lady Sundermere; its reflecting pool and walled citrus grove overlook the open sea.

title: Crestfall Manor
description: Named for its terraced battlements, this sandstone estate of the Crestfall family features an ornate belvedere tower and private chapel.

title: Hawklorn Hall
description: A red-brick mansion halfway down the cliff, famed for its aviary of trained falcons and its sunken rose garden.

title: Cliffhaven Estate
description: The fourth estate from the north, Cliffhaven is Highmarch’s grandest property by far. A lavish main manor stands atop a terraced rise, flanked by walled gardens, guest lodges, stables, kennels, an armory and its own private chapel. Carriage drives wind down to service yards, and a lofty belvedere pavilion offers sweeping views of the city and sea beyond.

title: Twinbrook Manors
description: The southernmost clutch of Highmarch’s cliff mansions is actually a twin estate: two near-identical manors separated by a formal reflecting pool and commemorative colonnade.

title: Sans Pareil Amphitheater
description: A grand, freestanding stone coliseum sited directly on Highmarch’s principal north–south thoroughfare from the Twin Gates. Its tiered marble seating—arranged in a gentle semi-circle—rises around a broad central stage, framed by ornate proscenium arches and capped with fluttering pennants. Though visible from the cliff-edge mansions above, its position on the main road makes it equally accessible to visiting nobles, merchants, and clergy. By day, it hosts ceremonial processions and oratory contests; by dusk, its acoustics fill with the strains of chamber orchestras, touring troupes’ dramas, and the hush of spectators under lamplit torches.

title: Crystal Palm Conservatory
description: Sited at the northern edge of Highmarch, the Crystal Palm Conservatory is a pioneering circular glass dome set into a dignified granite rotunda. Inside, rare tropical palms, luminous orchids, and vine-wrapped pillars flourish beneath the curved panes, their leaves whispering in gentle piped breezes. A concentric gallery rings the central planting bed, where silk-cushioned benches invite patrons to admire the exotic blooms—and to imagine distant, sun-soaked shores. Its blend of cutting-edge glasswork and stone architecture makes it both a scientific marvel and a favorite promenade for Highmarch’s elite.

title: Concord Park
description: A gated, oak-shaded enclave where emissaries meditate between sessions, its winding paths punctuated by open-air pavilions.

title: Diplomat's Court
description: A pale-stone complex of chancery offices, where scrolls are drawn up, sealed, and dispatched.

title: The Exchange
description: Mercenary brokerages occupy these interconnected townhouses, each representing one of Kolnmark’s famed companies.

title: Iron Gate Lodge
description: The district’s largest hostelry, its twin iron portcullises and honor-guarded entrance set the tone for martial hospitality.

title: The Vault of Accordance
description: A vaulted, oak-paneled repository adjacent to Diplomat’s Court. Here visiting delegations consult codices of regional law, treaties past and present, and local customaries. Private study alcoves and on-call scribes ensure that envoys can research, translate, and commission exact copies of any document under discreet candlelight.

title: Goldedge Terrace
description: A graceful row of three-story brick townhouses set beneath iron-filigree balconies. Many feature small shopfronts—tailors’ windows or apothecary displays—beneath the families’ private quarters.

title: Twin Gate Lodges
description: Converted guardhouses flanking the city wall’s inner gate. Their vaulted ground floors now feed and house well-to-do lodgers.

title: Silvered Ivy Gardens
description: A sunken public square planted with espaliered fruit trees and clipped hedges. Every Saturday, local makers set up stalls beneath the linden boughs.

title: Many-Hued Chapel
description: A modest white-stone church built into the wall’s curtain, its stained-glass windows gleaming in morning light. The resident priest doubles as a notary for district affairs.

title: The Quill & Ledger Office
description: A discreet two-story stone building. Its ground-floor reading room and public counters serve Goldedge’s residents for notarial filings, household registrations, and guild paperwork, while a narrow oak-paneled stair leads upstairs to clerks’ offices where ledgers are kept by candlelight.

title: Mastermaker Park
description: A broad, trimmed‐hedge square in the northwest, laid out with flowering beds, winding paths, and sculpted stone benches. Rising in the park’s center, a crystal‐domed gazebo of aquamarine stone and filigreed spires hosts guild demonstrations, minstrels’ performances, and seasonal fairs.

title: Artisan Row
description: A large group of small retail shops opening up onto the park, each showcasing the district’s finest copperware, leather goods, glassware, and finely woven cloths.

title: The Ember & Anvil
description: A large timber-framed eatery near the East Gate, its roaring hearth and iron-forged décor serving molten iron ale and blackened roast to workshop hands and contract brokers alike.

title: The Silver Bell Taproom
description: Perched on Forge Street, known for its spiced peppercorn ale, nightly bardic recitals, and cordial welcome to both local journeymen and visiting dignitaries.

title: Moonfire Kilns
description: Nestled at Twinreach’s southern edge, a horseshoe of compact workshops surrounds a shared courtyard of glowing embers. Here master glassblowers forge moonfire glass, a rare mineral-infused crystal that absorbs daylight and softly radiates at night—shaping everything from lantern lenses and inlaid jewelry to luminescent display spheres that light the courtyard long after the kilns cool.

title: Hallowed Market
description: A circular plaza ringed with linden trees and covered stalls, where exotic dyes, enchanted inks, and rare implements change hands in the open air.

title: Twinforge Atelier
description: Twin domes of burnished bronze and slate shelter the royal Metallurgists’ Guild. One hall’s roaring hearths forge iron and steel; the other tempers gold, silver, and gemstone‐inlaid alloys.

title: Forgebinder Hall
description: A grand marble‐faced pavilion overlooking Crafthallow Square and the border of Swordcrest and Highmarch. Inside, vaulted galleries display prototype weapons and armor, and sculpted reliefs honor Kolnmark’s greatest smiths.

title: Gilded Crescent Workshops
description: A horseshoe of massive brick and timber workshops on the northern edge, where tapestry masters, glassblowers, and gemcutters produce luxury goods destined for Velvet Court and trading caravans.

title: Loomwrights' Guildhall
description: A vaulted sandstone hall adorned with stained‐glass skylights. Inside, master weavers gather to negotiate commissions for noble courts and apprentice the next generation of tapestry artists.

title: Gearcrafters' Guildhall
description: A soaring iron‐and‐stone building, where clockwork engineers and intricate machinists draft contracts and supervise the crafting of precision mechanisms for city defenses and luxury curios.

title: House of Caldara Spa
description: A two-tiered marble crepidoma ringed with classical colonnades. Its eight hot springs vary in mineral composition for health and beauty treatments.

title: Garden of Sighs
description: A terraced grove of moon-lit fountains and jasmine arbors, where guests whisper secrets under lantern light.

title: Velvet Embrace
description: The district’s most lavish bordello, its velvet-lined salons and perfumed baths draw nobles who demand privacy and perfection.

title: Amber Lamp Tavern
description: A tavern nearby Envoy’s Rest, famed for importing rare Hissai wines and Fesselburg teas, with live minstrel recitals at dusk.

title: The Pavilion
description: A marble kiosk in the spa’s shadow, where artisan chocolatiers, silversmiths, and perfumers display their finest wares to well-heeled passersby.
